CENTRE NUMBER

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 211, 905, 255]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 297, 329, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 339, 415, 375]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper. No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 390, 386, 407]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 719, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 500, 767, 545]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions. Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 554, 759, 585]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 698, 92]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating resistance using the circuit shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 98, 776, 320]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 336, 533, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 367, 146, 386]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 367, 920, 401]]<|/det|>
The student measures the potential difference \(V_{1}\) across the resistor \(\mathbf{R}_{\mathbf{A}}\) and the current \(I_{1}\) in the circuit. Figs. 1.2 and 1.3 show the voltmeter and ammeter scales.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 411, 771, 536]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 549, 383, 568]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 549, 688, 568]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 580, 181, 599]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 580, 737, 599]]<|/det|>
Write down the readings shown on the scales in Figs. 1.2 and 1.3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 612, 918, 631]]<|/det|>
<form>V_{1} = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 644, 920, 663]]<|/det|>
<form>I_{1} = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 660, 920, 679]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 688, 181, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 680, 806, 710]]<|/det|>
Calculate the resistance \(R_{1}\) of the resistor \(\mathbf{R}_{\mathbf{A}}\) using the equation \(R_{1} = \frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 750, 920, 769]]<|/det|>
<form>R_{1} = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 750, 920, 769]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 593, 92]]<|/det|>
The student connects a resistor \(\mathbf{R}_{\mathbf{B}}\) in series with \(\mathbf{R}_{\mathbf{A}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
She measures the potential difference \(V_{2}\) across the two resistors \(\mathbf{R}_{\mathbf{A}}\) and \(\mathbf{R}_{\mathbf{B}}\) combined and the current \(I_{2}\) in the circuit.

<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 918, 120]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating whether the diameter of a pendulum bob affects the period of a pendulum. The period is the time taken for one complete oscillation of the pendulum. Fig. 3.1 shows a pendulum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 448, 151]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.2 shows one complete oscillation.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 188, 687, 380]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 498, 457, 515]]<|/det|>
The student has the following apparatus:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 529, 848, 545]]<|/det|>
pendulum bobs made of polystyrene with diameters 1 cm, 2 cm, 3 cm, 4 cm and 5 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 543, 489, 560]]<|/det|>
a supply of thread and a pair of scissors

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 559, 301, 575]]<|/det|>
clamp and stand.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 605, 920, 638]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate whether the diameter of a pendulum bob affects the period of a pendulum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 653, 218, 669]]<|/det|>
You should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 685, 581, 701]]<|/det|>
* list additional apparatus that you would require

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 715, 655, 732]]<|/det|>
* explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 747, 568, 763]]<|/det|>
* state the key variables that you would control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 778, 918, 810]]<|/det|>
* draw a table with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (You are **not** required to enter any readings in the table.)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 824, 777, 841]]<|/det|>
* explain briefly how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 707, 91]]<|/det|> A student is determining the weight of a load using a balancing method. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 410, 121]]<|/det|> Fig. 4.1 shows the apparatus used. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 128, 876, 260]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 275, 532, 293]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 306, 920, 339]]<|/det|> The student places the metre rule on the pivot and adjusts its position so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 352, 816, 371]]<|/det|> He places a load \(\mathbf{P}\) on the metre rule so that its centre is exactly at the \(30.0 \text{cm}\) mark. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 384, 542, 402]]<|/det|> He records the distance \(a\) between \(\mathbf{P}\) and the pivot. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 413, 917, 435]]<|/det|> \[a = \frac{19.8\mathrm{cm}}{15.0\mathrm{cm}}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 452, 920, 485]]<|/det|> He places a load \(\mathbf{Q}\) of weight \(Q = 1.0 \text{N}\) on the metre rule and adjusts the position of \(\mathbf{Q}\) so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 500, 712, 517]]<|/det|> He measures the distance \(b\) between the centre of load \(\mathbf{Q}\) and the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 530, 920, 564]]<|/det|> He repeats the procedure, with the load \(\mathbf{P}\) remaining at the \(30.0 \text{cm}\) mark, using \(Q\) values of \(2.0 \text{N}\), \(3.0 \text{N}\), \(4.0 \text{N}\) and \(5.0 \text{N}\). All the readings are recorded in Table 4.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 577, 539, 594]]<|/det|> Table 4.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 606, 717, 776]]<|/det|>
\(Q/\mathrm {N}\)\(b/\mathrm {cm}\)\(\frac {1}{Q}/\frac {1}{N}\)
1.040.0
2.019.5
3.013.5
4.010.5
5.07.5
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 802, 144, 821]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 798, 707, 826]]<|/det|> For each value of \(Q\), calculate \(\frac{1}{Q}\) and record the result in the table. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 803, 920, 821]]<|/det|> [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 79, 146, 98]]<|/det|>
